ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Do you normally work (or attend school) during the day and sleep at night? (If the individiaul is unemployed and out of school, ask about his/her usual time of activity instead?
What is your normal work (or school) and sleep schedule
Notes: 1 = Always works nights, sleeps during the day; 2 = schedule rotates/Shift Work; 3 = Other, Describe: ; If response = 2: 1 =day Shift (approximately 7 am - 3 pm); 2 = Evening Shift (approximately 3 pm - 11 pm); 3 = Night Shift (approximately 11 pm - 7 am); 4 = Other:

ElementDescription: What shift schedule do you most often work?
At what time do you usually go to bed?
At what time do you usually go to bed? On a workday or school day?
At what time do you usually go to bed? On a non-work or non-school day
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep? On a workday or school day?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep? On a non work or non school day?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep? At what to do you usually wake up?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep? On a workday or school day?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep? On a non-work day or non-school day?
How long does it take for you to become fully awake from regular sleep?
Do you use an alarm clock to wake up in the morning?
Do you have great difficulty waking up in the morning?
Do you often have so much trouble waking up that an alarm clock wont wake you up and you have to use other methods to wake up?
Describe those other methods to wake yourself up:
When you wake up in the morning or from a nap, do you feel "out of it" and ocnsued?
How long does it take you to fully awaken?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night?. On a workday or school day?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night?. On a non-work or non-school day?
Do you usually follow the same sleep schedule (no more than a 1 hour difference in slep and wake times) onb both work/school and non work/school days?
How many hours of sleep per night do you think you need to feel fully rested the next day?
Do you feel awake and refereshed after sleeping?
How often do you remember your dreams? That is, dreams that occur during your regular sleep and not while napping.
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Rarely; 2 = Sometimes; 3 = Often (5-15 per times per month); 4 =Almost always (16-30 times per month); 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: How often do you take naps? If respondent never naps, SKIP to sleep deprivation
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Rarely; 2 = Sometimes; 3 = Often (5-15 per times per month); 4 =Almost always (16-30 times per month); 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: At what times of the day do you usually take naps?
How many hours and minutes of sleep do you usually get when you take a nap?
Do you have great difficulty waking up from naps?
How often do you dream when you nap?
Notes: 0 = Never; 1 = Rarely; 2 = Sometimes; 3 = Often (5-15 per times per month); 4 =Almost always (16-30 times per month); 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: Are these dreams very intense, detailed and vivid, like watching a movie?
How difficult is it for you to adapt to a sleep loss of 3 hours or more (i.e. sleeping 3 or more hours less than you noramlly do the night before?)
Notes: 0 = Not at all difficult; 1 = Not very difficult; 2 = Somewhat difficult; 3 = Very difficult; 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your modd (being sadder or happier)
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 2 = Improves; 3 = Worsens; 4 = Both; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your tendency to be irritable?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 2 = Improves; 3 = Worsens; 4 = Both; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your ability to get your work done?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 2 = Improves; 3 = Worsens; 4 = Both; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to how much you eat?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 2 = Improves; 3 = Worsens; 4 = Both; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your desire for chocolate or sweets?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 2 = Improves; 3 = Worsens; 4 = Both; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: How quickly after this loss of sleep, do you return to your usual self if you are allowed to sleep as much as you like?
Notes: 1 = Within 1 day or less; 2 = 2 to 3 days; 3 = 4 or 5 days; 4 = Over 5 days; 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: Do you prefer to keep a regular sleep schedule (i.e. one that does not change much fro one night to the next)?
If you do not keep your regular sleep schedule, how much do you feel "off" (i.e. not your regular self) the next day?
Notes: 0 = None, feel the same; 1 = Yes,somewhat off; 2 = Yes a great deal off; 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: When you are traveling EAST by air and your cross over several time zones, how quickly do you return to your usual sleeping pattern?
Notes: 1 = Within 1 day or less; 2 = 2 to 3 days; 3 = 4 or 5 days; 4 = Over 5 days; 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: What about when you are traveling WEST by air over several time zones?
Notes: 1 = Within 1 day or less; 2 = 2 to 3 days; 3 = 4 or 5 days; 4 = Over 5 days; 9 = Don't know

ElementDescription: Do you consider yourself to be a morning person ('early bird"), an evening person ("night owl"). Or neither?
Do you consider yourself to be a morning person ('early bird"), an evening person ("night owl"). Or neither? How strong is your preference?
INTERVIEWER: Does respondent consistently fall asleep very late (i.e. 12 a.m. or later) at night AND characterize him/herself as a "night owl" with a "strong preference"?

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): at what time do you usually go to sleep (i.e. feel sleepy and ready to go to bed?)

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): at what time do you usually go to sleep (i.e. feel sleepy and ready to go to bed?)At what time do you usually wake up?

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): Are these usual sleep and wake times always about the same (i.e. each day during a week of vacation)?

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): Do you wake up on your own (i.e. without an alarm or other assistance)?
Have you ever tried to force yourself to fall asleep at an (earlier) time than your usual bed time?
When you tried to shift your sleep schedule to an earlier bedtime (at least 1 to 2 hours earlier), did you have difficulty falling asleep?
Do attempts to change your sleep/wake schedule tend to make your sleeping difficulties worse?
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights?
Notes: Can be reported in weeks, months, or years

ElementDescription: How old were you when you first began going to sleep very late without being able to adjust your schedule when you tried?
How old were you the last time you experienced these problems?
Do you currently experience these problems?
How much have your late bedtime and inability to adjust your schedule upset or distressed you?
Notes: 0 = no distress/impairment and 10 = very severe problems

Notes: 0 = no distress/impairment and 10 = very severe problems

ElementDescription: What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your relationships with family members?

ElementDescription: What number describes how much this eveningness tendencuy has affected your performance in school/work or your relationships with your co-workers, employers, teachers or classmates?
Notes: 0 = no distress/impairment and 10 = very severe problems
